dt: {bc}to discharge completely (as from an accusation or obligation)
{bc}to conduct (oneself) usually satisfactorily especially under stress
{bc}to pay off (something, such as a claim or debt)

pt: {sc}behave{/sc} {sc}conduct{/sc} {sc}deport{/sc} {sc}comport{/sc} {sc}acquit{/sc} mean to act or to cause oneself to do something in a certain way. {sc}behave{/sc} may apply to the meeting of a standard of what is proper or decorous.
{sc}conduct{/sc} implies action or behavior that shows the extent of one's power to control or direct oneself.
{sc}deport{/sc} implies behaving so as to show how far one conforms to conventional rules of discipline or propriety.

pt.t: the hero {it}deported{/it} himself in accord with the code of chivalry

pt: {sc}comport{/sc} suggests conduct measured by what is expected or required of one in a certain class or position.
{sc}acquit{/sc} applies to action under stress that deserves praise or meets expectations.

pt.t: {it}acquitted{/it} herself well in her first assignment

pt: {sc}exculpate{/sc} {sc}absolve{/sc} {sc}exonerate{/sc} {sc}acquit{/sc} {sc}vindicate{/sc} mean to free from a charge. {sc}exculpate{/sc} implies a clearing from blame or fault often in a matter of small importance.

pt.t: {it}exculpating{/it} himself from the charge of overenthusiasm

pt: {sc}absolve{/sc} implies a release either from an obligation that binds the conscience or from the consequences of disobeying the law or committing a sin.
{sc}exonerate{/sc} implies a complete clearance from an accusation or charge and from any attendant suspicion of blame or guilt.
{sc}acquit{/sc} implies a formal decision in one's favor with respect to a definite charge.

{sc}vindicate{/sc} may refer to things as well as persons that have been subjected to critical attack or imputation of guilt, weakness, or folly, and implies a clearing effected by proving the unfairness of such criticism or blame.

et: Middle English {it}aquiten,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}aquiter,{/it} from {it}a-,{/it} prefix forming transitive verbs (going back to Latin {it}ad-{/it} {et_link|ad-|ad-}) + {it}-quiter,{/it} verbal derivative of {it}quite{/it} "free, discharged" {ma}{mat|quit:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: to discharge completely (as from an accusation or obligation)
to conduct (oneself) usually satisfactorily especially under stress
to pay off (something, such as a claim or debt)

dt: {bc}to act or behave in a specified way
used to express approval or (less commonly) disapproval of someone's behavior or performance

dt.t: The soldiers {it}acquitted themselves{/it} well/honorably in battle.
The young actress {it}acquitted herself{/it} extremely well/capably in her first film.
He {it}acquitted himself{/it} poorly in handling the controversy.

shortdef: to act or behave in a specified way —used to express approval or (less commonly) disapproval of someone's behavior or performance
